awd_titl_txt: Multiscale Mechanobiology of Growth and Remodeling During Wound Healing
awd_abstract_narration:
During wound healing, a series of growth and remodeling processes transform an initial fibrin clot into a scar primarily made out of collagen, which usually has inferior mechanical properties compared with normal skin. While progress has been made towards understanding how the mechanical properties of the tissue change during wound healing, much less is known about how local remodeling of the extracellular matrix (ECM) at the cell level during would healing leads to the new mechanical properties at the tissue level. The objective of this project is to understand how the extracellular matrix (ECM) is remodeled at the microscale by fibroblasts, and how these changes of the ECM lead to the observed changes at the tissue (macro) scale.  This will be tackled through a combination of experimental and computational modeling efforts.  The framework will increase knowledge about how the way in which cells sense and respond to their mechanical environment at the microscale is linked to tissue level growth and remodeling.  By advancing understanding in this area, it may be possible to translate the knowledge to improved interventions to support wound healing - a key problem in medicine.  In order to further broaden the impact of the award, the open-source software developed through this research will be made available to the community through Github.  In addition, the researchers will organize a workshop at a national conference focused on multiscale modeling of biological systems in order to train the next generation of scientists. The work will further be complemented with educational and mentoring activities aimed at increasing representation of minorities by continuing to participate in the Purdue?s Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship and Pathways to the Faculty Programs. 

The overall goal of this project is to elucidate how the underlying cellular events at the microscale are connected to the macroscale mechanics during would healing. It is hypothesized that growth and remodeling at the macroscale can be predicted with a multiscale model based on microscale ECM remodeling.  This process is expected to be dependent on fiber degradation, fiber deposition, and cell-driven contraction. In Objective 1, the project will connect a finite element tissue level model to a detailed microscale model where a fiber network is remodeled by a fibroblast population represented as agents. In Objective 2, the growth and remodeling of fibrin and collagen gels seeded with fibroblasts subjected to an initial deformation and controlled cytokine concentration will be tracked for days to weeks. These measurements will be used to calibrate the computational model. The model will be further validated in Objective 3 by experimentally perturbing the system to alter collagen deposition, fiber degradation, and cell contractility. Finally, the project will create an in vitro wound model consisting of a fibrin domain inside a collagen gel and compare changes in geometry with the computational model's prediction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Soft tissues like skin respond to mechanical forces by a process called growth and remodeling, which means creation of new skin or a change in skin properties such as stiffness. Additionally, after injury, the process of wound healing entails replacing the clot, made out of the biopolymer fibrin, with a collagen-based structure that is similar to the native skin structure. However, often wound healing does not result in skin with the same properties as the original tissue, but rather leaves behind a scar. Growth, remodeling, and wound healing are difficult to predict and control because the observed changes at the tissue level, at a scale on the order of centimeters, are actually controlled by the coordinated action of individual fibroblast cells and their surrounding extracellular matrix (ECM), at a scale on the order of micrometers. This project, led by Adrian Buganza Tepole at Purdue University, and Sarah Calve at University of Colorado at Boulder, helped elucidate how the tissue level mechanical forces and deformations are sensed by individual cells in a process called mechanosensing, and how the activity of cells on their ECM is reflected at the tissue level as growth, remodeling, and wound healing.

The team of investigators proposed theoretical and computational models of fibroblast mechanobiology connecting events at the micro-, meso- and macroscopic scales. Tissues were modeled using finite element models at the macroscopic scale, with mechanical properties derived from models of discrete fiber networks at the mesoscale. Cells were modeled either as particles embedded in the fiber network, or assumed to experience average deformations directly based on deformations from the finite element model, without the explicit fiber network of the mesoscale. In either case, a microscale model of how fibroblast cells bind to the ECM was created to understand how tissue deformations led to different fibroblast mechanosensing. Cellular activity as a result of the mechanosensing process was also modeled. In particular, fibroblasts in the model can exert forces on the ECM, break down existing ECM, and deposit new collagen. This cellular action is integrated into the finite element model, producing growth, remodeling, and healing of the tissue in the simulations. Extensive experimental work on fibrin gels was conducted to determine the mechanical properties of these materials, as well as the mechanics of the fiber networks at the mesoscale. Additional data on wound healing mechanics was gathered from an extensive review of the literature. The calibrated models were able to reproduce the healing response of wounds in mice. Thus, this project enabled fundamental understanding of multiscale mechanobiology and its role in wound healing as originally envisioned.

The application of this fundamental knowledge to societal problems is also underway. Wound healing is commonplace in clinical practice. The team focused in particular on the application of the model to understand wound healing after lumpectomy surgery. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women and lumpectomy (breast conserving surgery to remove breast tumors) is used in approximately half of the cases. However, the wound healing response can lead to complications and poor aesthetic outcomes that impact survivors? quality of life. Applying the computational models developed through thuis award to simulate lumpectomy wounds, the researchers have  proposed novel hypotheses linking patient factors such as breast size, breast composition, tumor location, and tumor size, to the wound healing outcome in these patients. Thus, understanding and modeling wound healing mechanistically can advance medicine, lumpectomy planning specifically, in the near future.

The software and codes developed through this research have been made available to the community through public Github repositories. Several graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds participated in conducting this research. The new scientific knowledge and data has been shared to the community through peer-reviewed journal publications. Lastly, to reach an even wider audience, the Buganza Tepole team developed an elasticity solver in the popular video game Minecraft.

 


Last Modified: 11/04/2023
Modified by: Sarah Calve
